entry.title: COMPSCI 753 - Lecture Notes - Stream-Sampling
entry.content:
Motivation

Since we cannot store alllll the stream, we store a uniform sample of the stream to answer queries

Goal

  • Choose small number to keep in memory out of large number of elements
  • Sample single elements from the stream uniformly at random
  • Same probability of the sample to be chosen
  • Draw sample over the stream, not the universe

Two sampling problems

  • P1: Sample a fixed proportion of elements in the stream AND the sample size is m/10 given the stream of m elements
  • P2: Maintain a random sample of fixed size over an infinite stream && The sample size is fixed. s for at any time k

Fixed proportion

Scenario

  • Search engine receives a stream of tuples (user, query, time)
  • Question: How many users run the same query in a single day?
  • Memory: We have space to store 1/10 of the stream

Naive solution:

  • Generate a random integer in (0…9) for each query
  • Store the query if the integer is 0; otherwise, discard.

Problem for naive solution:

  • If each user send x queries once and d queries twice (x+2d)
  • Question becomes what the fraction of queries by an average user are duplicated
  • Because we need to categorizes the sample, the sample size becomes a problem

Answer would be: d/(x+d) (True solution)

But we cannot approximately answer the question

How to come up with approximate solution

  • Out of x query (singleton), we query 10% of them

    • P = x/10

  • For 2d duplicate query. Case 1: Both {qi’, qi’} sampled. Case 2: First of {qi’, qi’} sampled. Case 3: Second of {qi’, qi’} sampled.

    • p = d/100 + 9d/100 + 9d/100

  • Overall:

    • (d/100) / (x/10 + d/100 + 18d/100) = d / 10x+19d

Above is the approximate solution according to the sampling scheme

Solution: Sample Users

We use the hash function and hash the users (not queries) into 10 buckets uniformly
Then pick user ID in the first bucket.

Generalized solution: Fixed proportion

  • Stream tuples with keys

    • Key is some subset of each tuples components
    • e.g. tuple is (user, serach, time) -> key is user
    • Choice of key depends on applications

  • Task: Get a sample of a/b fraction of the stream (e.g. 30%)

    • Hash each tuple’s key uniformly into b buckets (e.g. 10 buckets)
    • Pick the tuple if its hash value is in the first a bucket (e.g., the first 3 buckets)

Fixed size

entry.title: Clean Architecture - 0
entry.content:
Notes taken from this video

Good architecture is important

Start from a story:

2 architects John and Jane both working on a building but in two different style.

John is an expert in classic architecture building, He keeps pushing the boundary of architectural design using cutting edge technologies. He uses all of his favorite tools. His design is elegant yet state of the art.

Once he finished the design, he just hand that to the crew and move on for his next masterpiece. Once the building is finished he goes to the opening ceremony and read the reward of his accomplishment.

But Jane has a very different approach to the architecture. First, she start chatting with the future inhabitants in the building. I.e. the employees, the maintenance group and even the construction worker. She finds out what they need, what they found valuable, and what the experience level of the construction is.

Then she designs the architecture with he inhabitants in mind. She consider their need with each decision that they were made.

Once she finished the blueprint, she doesn’t just hand it to the worker. Instead she work side by side with them, help them understand the design, and improve the design, and solve the problems that are arrived.

Those two approaches is going to create two different architecture.
So, which one would the work like?

That story drives us to the CLEAN architecture.

entry.title: Daily Readings - Day 3 (Toastmaster!)
entry.content:
Yay tosatmasters!!!!

It is scary to talk in front of people, or even just stand up and talk without people.

It is also quite scary that you cannot say what you are thinking in a structured way.

ANND here we comes for toastmasters biztalk. You get a chance to challenge yourself by speaking in front of people with a topic and get evaluated.

It can be scary in your first time, but when you try it once, you can never stop. It is fun to talk and share ideas, and more importantly, you gets to know where you did good and bad. You are improving

entry.title: Daily Reading - Day 4 Toastmasters Again!
entry.content:
Ok toastmasters

This week toastmaster is a demo night. So more people coming and we got better food (2m long pizzas!)

Today I got a chance to talk about what things that I can teach to the audience. I did what I think worse than last week because I started talking about coding and end up with something different.

I need to structure my entire idea of the talk before I start it.

Meanwhile, we had a guy who stand there and remain slient for a while… He had to take a seat and process until he is ready. And… he made it!!!!

entry.title: Daily readings - Day 1
entry.content:
https://matt-rickard.com/the-programmable-web/

This article introduced two things of the programmable web - bookmarklet (web small programs that change the browser) and user scripts (scripts that provide extra functionality of the particular website)

In the end the article raise the secutiry vs the userscripts and let the readers thing why not having both the security and the userscipts.

entry.title: Learn Vim? Day 0
entry.content:
Vim basics

i for insert
hjkl for directions
a for go to the first position
shift a for go to the end of the line
g for go to the start of the file
shift g for go to the eof

and there is more…

entry.title: Interface Oriented Programming
entry.content:
Welp what is IOP? Like what even is Interface?

Just think of a socket plug. All the manfuncer company would use the same interface standard to manufact those plugs. The stuff that are inside does not matter. Even if one plug is not working, we can just get another one that has the same standard.

entry.title: Ihaka LEcture 2022 I
entry.content:
Domain Specific languages.
Things aboutinsulin

R packages
Algricolae

The grammar of experimental designs
Work by the lectuer

About Concerte syntax and bstract syntax

Concerte: external representation of a lauguage
Abstract: internal representation of a language

Proposition:
Design of abstract and concrete syntax can aid both intra and inter personal communitcation

E.g
Plant diversity effect on soil microbial function and enzymes are stronger than warming in a grassland experiement

3 Hyposises

More into the paper:
Plants diversity & plts are divided into three subplots
Different heat treatments

This is in fact a Split-plot-design

Edibble - lectuered designed library

  • Semantics of the syntactic sugar are alighed with basic terms in experiemental design
  • Experiemntal; structure are built up step by step
  • A numbr of downsides

Easy and quick visulaisation:
degguest degustation
A simple function called autoplot
Pass in edibble plot.

ggplot functions

Overall an interesting lecture : )

The end

entry.title: MoSCoW Method
entry.content:
Features:
Must-Have: (The project would fail if the following features/functionalities is not met)
Answering format:

  • What is this feature/functionality?
  • Where would this feature be on the webportal? (E.g. the searching for jobs would be a new page on the web portal)
  • The ideal steps for a user to use this feature/functionality (e.g. Step 1 The user clicks on the top search for job bar. Step 2 The user enters the input. Step 3 The user sees a list of jobs with titles, location… on their browser, Step 4 The user click on one of the jobs and get redirected to a new page on another tab
  • Briefly explain the connections between this and other features (if any)

Note: The above format would help us the best to understand more precisely thoughts about a feature in your mind. You do not have to follow the entire format if you really cannot think of any, but it would be good to do so. : )

Should Have: (The project would not fail if the following features/functionalities are not met, but the project would be tougher to gain attractions)

Could Have: (The project is completely fine without the following features/functionalities. These are just some neat, interesting stuff but do not necessarily serve a greater purpose. This might be hard to distinguish from the should haves. My suggestions would be to consider how these features impact the value of our project to the users/customers)

Won’t Have: (The features that would likely be in the project, but for some reason, we can’t. Either time or resources do not allow us to implement these. We would like to keep those ideas and possibly move those to the categories above in the future: )

entry.content:
Just had a first meeting with the new project executives.

Good ideas come out from them

Say goodbye to Mr.Jason Ko : (

Projects are there for the students who can gain the MOST knowledge from it.

Need to think about a more structured way for the project workflow.

entry.title: What would happen with you and your peers after 10 years?
entry.content:
From this video
https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1kB4y1Q7nn?spm_id_from=333.1007.tianma.1-3-3.click&vd_source=60064b28be52500ccc945fd8bd7e934b

Yea what would happen after 10 year with you?
In 10 years time, we would get married, have a children, earn more money, and etc. But that is just one way of living, your peers who are in acedmics might become a professor in some famous univeristies. Everything can happen in 10 year time.
You might be wonder, what are the key factors that made the differences? Welp we can’t find any.
Is it hardwork? Maybe, but there are a lot of people who did hardwork, but they you would see their grades was actaully going down for some reason. They have a lot of pressure and they seems to be stucked in a dead cycle.

But again, you cannot success without any hardwork. As a result, hardworking is the at least thing that we can do.

Pain is inevitable, suffering is optional

There are many possible roads of your life, but it does not mean u will be stuck in one road. You can switch to any other roads you want, but there are cost when you switch between the roads.

逆水行舟，不进则退。
You cannot stay there, you must keep going up and up.
As a programmer, you need to keep going up and up. Learn more and more.

A breif summary:
1，同一学校毕业的，也能发展差别很大，世界是荒谬混沌的。但持续的努力是个人唯一能把握的事，否则只能被命运掌控住。
2，不同的道路都可追求自己努力的上限，不管个人运气好坏，不要相信能平着躺平，世界充满着争夺挤压抢占，充满着洗牌，不进则退。
3，生活架构要尽可能搭建在自己身上，而不是依靠外界和他人，持续创造价值，持续成长，才能抵抗未知的风险。
4，收入是跳跃式增长的，提供的价值上台阶了，收入才会跳跃式增长。收入和提供的价值是个价格和价值的关系，可能会有德不配位和通货膨胀，最终会有价值回归，专注价值提升。
5，请提高抗挫折能力，请习惯日常的挫折，这就是人生常态，这个世界没有答案。

The End ~
